> I saw that there are two calls to the method initialize that calls _parse_attributes. Every time _parse_attributes is called the value of the variable _attributes is set to empty.

No, there is only one call to `initialize()` [here](https://github.com/bcit-ci/CodeIgniter/blob/3.0.4/system/libraries/Pagination.php#L342) and again only one to `_parse_attributes()`, [here](https://github.com/bcit-ci/CodeIgniter/blob/3.0.4/system/libraries/Pagination.php#L359).

@narfbg  Yes, there is one call on the code. But the constructor is called twice. One for the config file and other for the config on the controller. You can simulate with my code and you will see it.

@narfbg Sorry, it's not the constructor that it's called twice. It's really the initialize() method. var_dump($params); on the beginning of the method shows: ``` array (size=16) 'full_tag_open' => string '
' (length=32) 'full_tag_close' => string '
' (length=6) 'first_link' => boolean false 'last_link' => boolean false 'next_link' => string '' (length=32) 'next_tag_open' => string '' (length=24) 'next_tag_close' => string '' (length=7) 'prev_link' => string '' (length=31) 'prev_tag_open' => string '' (length=24) 'prev_tag_close' => string '' (length=7) 'cur_tag_open' => string '' (length=26) 'cur_tag_close' => string '' (length=7) 'attributes' => array (size=1) 'class' => string 'item' (length=4) 'use_page_numbers' => boolean true 'page_query_string' => boolean true 'first_url' => string '?per_page=1' (length=11) array (size=3) 'base_url' => string 'http://localhost/' (length=43) 'total_rows' => int 67 'per_page' => int 10 ``` So, I really think it's called twice. But maybe somewhere else in the code. I'll look for it and reopen the issue if I found something. Sorry to bother.
`initialize()` is supposed to reset the configuration to default values, that's the expected behavior.

@narfbg so, you are basically saying that I can either have one config file in the config folder or the config in the controller but not both at the same time. I think that's not good because I only put in the config folder what is common to every controller and I put the specific config in the controller. But following your idea, now I would have to delete my pagination.php config file and repeat all the common code in every controller.

> @narfbg so, you are basically saying that I can either have one config file in the config folder or the config in the controller but not both at the same time. I think that's not good because I only put in the config folder what is common to every controller and I put the specific config in the controller. But following your idea, now I would have to delete my pagination.php config file and repeat all the common code in every controller.

It used to work like that in 3.0.0.  After upgrading to 3.1.0 the `initialize()` method is bypassing the `pagination.php` config file.

Very disappointing as this idea totally ignores the DRY method... AND it will break previous installations of CodeIgniter without any mention of this "fix" in the official "How to Upgrade" notes.

ALL pagination within the project needs to share certain config options, but every Controller function will also need a few unique settings ... easy way to do this?  Otherwise, I have a crude workaround.

@sparky672 Your rant doesn't make any sense ...
- This is an issue from 2012, _way_ before the 3.0.0 release.
- The `initialize()` method has _never_ loaded the config on its own. The config has always been passed by `CI_Loader` when you load the library.
- This behavior hasn't changed since the 3.0.0 release.

I can only explain my observations.  Yesterday I took a working project running 3.0.0 and upgraded it to 3.1.0 by replacing only the `system` files.  I changed absolutely nothing within my Controllers or `application` files.

Here are my simple observations:

**v3.0.0** - all pagination instances are using my `application/config/pagination.php` configuration file.

**v3.1.0** - all pagination instances are IGNORING my `application/config/pagination.php` configuration file.

Along with my sample code:

a single instance within a typical Controller function...

```
$config['base_url'] = '/class/function/' . $type . '/';   // <- UNIQUE to each Controller function
$config['uri_segment'] = 4;   // <- UNIQUE, depends on above setting

$this->load->library('pagination');
$this->pagination->initialize($config); 
$data['pagination'] = $this->pagination->create_links();
```

Common settings stored in `application/config/pagination.php`

---

As far as my rant:   You're going to have both common configuration settings for all pagination instances in your project _along with_ settings that are unique to each instance.  If having unique settings for multiple instances precludes being able to use `pagination.php`, then its own purpose is already defeated.  In order to use `pagination.php`, every instance of pagination would need identical URL structure, which makes it impossible to use on more than one Controller function.

I'm simply wondering how somebody would ever be able to use this `pagination.php` configuration file to their advantage.

> Yesterday I took a working project running 3.0.0 and upgraded it to 3.1.0 by replacing only the system files.

My guess is that you _think_ you took a 3.0.0 project, but it is not in fact 3.0.0. It may be an old 3.0.0-dev version, or some monkey-patched 2.x version ... who knows.

> Here are my simple observations:
> 
> v3.0.0 - all pagination instances are using my application/config/pagination.php configuration file.
> 
> v3.1.0 - all pagination instances are IGNORING my application/config/pagination.php configuration file.

No `CI_Pagination` instances are even aware of your config file. As I said - it's the Loader that reads and then passes the configuration to it. In other words, you're looking in the wrong place.

> As far as my rant: You're going to have both common configuration settings for all pagination instances in your project along with settings that are unique to each instance. If having unique settings for multiple instances precludes being able to use pagination.php, then its own purpose is already defeated. In order to use pagination.php, every instance of pagination would need identical URL structure, which makes it impossible to use on more than one Controller function.
> 
> I'm simply wondering how somebody would ever be able to use this pagination.php configuration file to their advantage.

If you looked at the code and/or the description of this issue, you'd know that only the 'attributes' configuration is reset. Everything else is kept until overriden with a different value.
This is why I said you're not making any sense.

> My guess is that you think you took a 3.0.0 project, but it is not in fact 3.0.0. It may be an old 3.0.0-dev version, or some monkey-patched 2.x version ... who knows.

Your guess is wrong.  [It was version 3.0.0](http://forum.codeigniter.com/thread-1657-post-7480.html#pid7480) (files dated March 30, 2015, 9:57 AM) that I downloaded and installed myself on April 5, 2015.

```
    define('CI_VERSION', '3.0.0');  // line 58 from system/core/CodeIgniter.php 
```

> In other words, you're looking in the wrong place.

Well, that may be true, since I'm only looking for an explanation here.

>  This is why I said you're not making any sense.

[The docs say](http://www.codeigniter.com/user_guide/libraries/pagination.html#setting-preferences-in-a-config-file): _"If you prefer not to set preferences using the above method, you can instead put them into a config file.  Simply create a new file called `pagination.php`, add the `$config` array in that file. Then save the file in `application/config/pagination.php` and it will be used automatically. You will NOT need to use `$this->pagination->initialize()` if you save your preferences in a config file"_.  

So can you simply explain how the same `pagination.php` config file can possibly be used for different pagination instances in various controller functions when each controller/function will have at least one pagination setting (such as `base_url`) that's unique to only that one controller/function?

`pagination.php` configuration would be ignored here:

```
// pagination.php configuration would be ignored here

$config['base_url'] = '/class/function/';   // <- UNIQUE to each Controller function
$config['uri_segment'] = 3;   // <- depends on above setting

$this->load->library('pagination');
$this->pagination->initialize($config);
$data['pagination'] = $this->pagination->create_links();
```

`pagination.php` configuration works here, but now there's no way to set `base_url` for just this one time:

```
// pagination.php configuration works here, but now there's no way to set base_url

$this->load->library('pagination');
$data['pagination'] = $this->pagination->create_links();
```

>  If you looked at the code and/or the description of this issue, you'd know that only the 'attributes' configuration is reset. Everything else is kept until overriden with a different value.

Okay, I took a step back and was able to reproduce this... only the `attributes` config item is reset.  **It would be great if this was mentioned someplace in the documentation.**  Since my `attributes` setting is common to all instances, putting it within my `pagination.php` configuration file seemed like a logical choice and, for whatever reason, that was working fine in my installation of v3.0.0.

So as long as you keep `$config['attributes']` out of the `pagination.php` config file, you can have global settings within `pagination.php` AND individual settings via `initialize()`.

Thanks for your time.
